Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "Where are the w:headers and w:header elements?" (#98) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody:
I understand that WordprocessingML got w:headers and w:header elements added on the standards, so that w:tcPr can have a w:headers child and the latest could have any amount of w:header elements as children.

I could not find any reference or matching element whatsoever to use it. How could one get a reference to these elements by class name?

> Annex M. (informative) Differences Between ECMA-376:2012 and ECMA-376:2006 
> 
> This annex is informative.
> 
> This annex highlights the differences between the versions of the Strict form of the Office Open XML schemas, as defined in ECMA-376:2012 and the schemas as defined by ECMA-376:2006.
> 
> ...
> - The header element (§17.4.18) was added
> - The headers element (§17.4.19) was added

And

> 17.4.18 header (Header Cell Reference)
> 
> This element specifies a reference, using a unique identifier, to a table header cell that is associated with the current table cell. The identifier representing the reference shall be stored on this element’s val attribute and is used to reference the unique identifier value of the id attribute of a header cell tc element of the current table.
> The contents of the table header cell tc element designated by the specific unique identifier in its id attribute shall be used as the table header information associated with the table cell that references that specific unique identifier.
> If this element is omitted or the value of the header cell identifier cannot be resolved, no header cell shall be associated with the current table cell.
> 
> ...
> 
> 17.4.19 headers (Header Cells Associated With Table Cell)
> 
> This element specifies the list of header cells, as specified by children header elements, that provide header information associated with the current table cell. Each header cell shall specify a unique identifier, as specified by the use of the attribute id on the header cell tc element. This element is typically used to gather header information about data and sub header cells.
> If this element is omitted or no children header element exists, no header cell shall be associated with the given table cell.
> 
> ```
> <w:tbl>
>   …
>   <w:tr>
>     …
>     <w:tc >
>       …
>     </w:tc>
>     <w:tc w:id="HeaderA">
>        …
>       <w:p>
>         <w:r>
>           <w:t>A</w:t>
>         </w:r>
>       </w:p>
>     </w:tc>
>     …
>   </w:tr>
>   <w:tr>
>     …
>     <w:tc w:id="HeaderC">
>       …
>       <w:p>
>         <w:r>
>           <w:t>C</w:t>
>         </w:r>
>       </w:p>
>     </w:tc>
>     <w:tc>
>       <w:tcPr>
>         …
>         <w:headers>
>           <w:header w:val="HeaderA" />
>           <w:header w:val="HeaderC" />
>         </w:headers>
>         …
>       </w:tcPr>
>       <w:p>
>         <w:r>
>           <w:t>x1</w:t>
>         </w:r>
>       </w:p>
>     </w:tc>
>     …
>   </w:tr>
> </w:tbl>
> ```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Add OpenXmlElement.StrictTranslateAttribute to handle strict translation" (#494) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody:
The previous implementation of this had multiple race conditions. This adds a special overload to OpenXmlElement to handle any strict translation needed by the attributes.

Fixes #480

Closed issue "OpenXmlSimpleType children do not implement equality" (#485) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Opened issue "Add support for emf/wmf images conversion into html " (#222) at OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools
Events.RelatedBody:
It's known issue that GDI consumes huge amounts of memory when dealing with emf/wmf.

On the other hand, image/x-emf, image/x-wmf are valid types of images in both OpenXML and RTF specs.

While it still possible to replace these images with converted analogs using OpenXML SDK, it would be useful to allow convert a document with them into html (instead of just ignoring silently).
It's much simpler to convert them into another format in ImageHandler(png, for instance, because Chrome and Firefox don't understand emf/wmf formats), instead of replacing the ImagePart.

Moreover, the changes are really small, and, as the benefit, give the responsibility to the consumer what to do with these formats (they can be ignored as well).

Thanks in advance
